Award.AwardTitle: Water, Drought and Snowpack Monitoring in the United States Using the EarthScope Plate Boundary Observatory GPS Network
Award.AbstractNarration:
Changes in water storage in aquifers, soils, lakes and glaciers cause the Earth to deform elastically in ways that can be detected using the Global Positioning System (GPS). We propose to study this water- related deformation at GPS stations in EarthScope?s Plate Boundary Observatory (PBO) and use these observations to estimate the variation of water loads over the continental United States. Given the longstanding importance of water and drought in the West, and the threat of climate change to water security across the entire USA, improvements in direct monitoring of the water cycle are of great social and economic relevance. By providing new data on water storage and the water cycle, this work has the potential to make a significant and positive impact on water management in the United States, in addition to improving the underlying science.

The goal of this work is to combine GPS load estimates with mass change estimates from NASA's GRACE satellite mission and independent information about hydrological systems and their boundaries to develop improved models for water redistribution. This study puts special emphasis on the all- important snowpack estimates for the Sierra Nevada and Rocky Mountains, and drought impacts on groundwater changes in California?s Central Valley and other principal aquifers in the USA. Specifically, over the next three years, we will: 1) reprocess all daily GPS position data to generate reliable series of seasonal and nonseasonal displacements; 2) correct all time series for offsets, transient displacements, and known atmospheric/oceanic loads; 3) invert for the spatiotemporal water loading across the continental USA; 4) constrain GPS mass changes with lower-resolution data from the GRACE mission to develop better estimates of water fluxes; 5) investigate mass changes of vulnerable mountain snowpack and groundwater aquifer systems in response to the current western USA drought; and 5) publish the results of this work as a set of data products and accompanying methodology for use by scientists and for possible operational use by water managers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Earth's surface is constantly deforming under the changing weight of water stored in soils, lakes, snowpack, and underground aquifers. These millimeter-level surface motions are too small to be sensed by humans, but they can be detected by continuously operating Global Positioning System (GPS) stations. Water storage, which reflects the sum total of water available to both natural and human systems, is increasingly important for assessing water security under a changing climate. It is also difficult to measure, since conventional observations of water in soil, snowpack, and aquifers are sparse and incomplete.


This project's central study analyzed surface deformation from NSF's Plate Boundary Observatory GPS network and used this information to recover a ten-year history of water storage change over the continental United States (Adusumilli et al., 2019). This marked the first time this analysis had been done systematically across such a large domain. This research also broke new ground by being the first study to jointly analyze observational data from GPS and from NASA's GRACE mission. GRACE directly observes the gravity signal from water mass changes over the entire planet, but it cannot achieve the spatial or temporal resolution possible with GPS. Together, the two datasets provided a complementary view of water storage extending from the continental scale down to that of regional watersheds. Among the findings of this work was that periods of drought 2007-2017 in the western USA are correlated with the El Nino/La Nina, but the pattern is opposite to that observed over the historical record. This has implications for future ocean-driven climate fluctuations in the West. The study also showed that large atmospheric rivers play a critical role in seasonal water storage increase in the western USA, underscoring the impact of that just a few large storms can have on water security in the region.


A sub-theme that emerged during the course of the project was deciphering the movement of some GPS stations whose motions were correlated with water storage changes, but which did not fit the pattern expected from increases and decreases in water weight (or loading) on Earth's surface. A first study (Silverii et al., 2019) found that water infiltration into karst aquifers in Italy's Apennine Mountains were responsible for large horizontal GPS motions due to aquifer expansion. The second (Silverii et al., 2020, published after the close of the project) found similar motion in the Sierra Nevada mountains to the south and west of Long Valley Caldera, CA, interpreted to be the result of water infiltration into granitic aquifers. Taken together, these studies are a roadmap for understanding the rich information content of GPS and for identifying locations where our current physical model is insufficient for predicting station motion due to hydrological forces.


A final offshoot of this project (Kraner et al., 2018) considered the impact of water on surface deformation at an even smaller scale, focusing on the forces responsible for GPS station motion in the area of the 2014 M6.0 South Napa Earthquake. While seasonal precipitation patterns and accompanying water storage changes could explain the vertical motion of GPS stations, horizontal motions did not follow the pattern expected from water loading. The study concluded that water pumping from local aquifers was responsible for large observed horizontal GPS motions, and that the resulting stresses were significant enough to have been a potential trigger for the South Napa earthquake.
